            "title": [
              [
                "Extension methods were introduced in C# 3.0. Extension methods extend and add behavior to existing types without creating a new derived type, recompiling, or otherwise modifying the original type. "
              ],
              [
                "They are especially helpful when you cannot modify the source of a type you are looking to enhance.",
                [["i"]]
              ],
              [
                " Extension methods may be created for system types, types defined by third parties, and types that you have defined yourself. The extension method can be invoked as though it were a member method of the original type. This allows for "
              ],
              ["Method Chaining", [["b"]]],
              [" used to implement a "],
              ["Fluent Interface", [["b"]]],
              ["."]
            ]

            "title": [
              [
                "static class StringExtensions\n{\n    public static string Shorten(this string text, int length) \n    {\n        return text.Substring(0, length);\n    }\n}\n\nclass Program\n{\n    static void Main()\n    {\n        // This calls method String.ToUpper()\n        var myString = \"Hello World!\".ToUpper();\n\n        // This calls the extension method StringExtensions.Shorten()\n        var newString = myString.Shorten(5); \n\n        // It is worth noting that the above call is purely syntactic sugar\n        // and the assignment below is functionally equivalent\n        var newString2 = StringExtensions.Shorten(myString, 5);\n    }\n}\n"
              ]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "code",
          "version": 9
        }
      },

                "Note that the syntactic convenience of calling an extension method via "
              ],
              ["originalTypeInstance.ExtensionMethod()", [["c"]]],
              [
                " is an optional convenience. The method can also be called in the traditional manner, so that the special first parameter is used as a parameter to the method."

              ["first argument of an extension method", [["i"]]],
              [" (which is accompanied by the "],
              ["this", [["c"]]],
              [" keyword) is the instance the extension method is called upon."]

          "created_by": "bb760e2d-d679-4b64-b2a9-03005b21870a",

          "ignore_block_count": true,
          "last_edited_by": "bb760e2d-d679-4b64-b2a9-03005b21870a",
          "last_edited_by_id": "bb760e2d-d679-4b64-b2a9-03005b21870a",
          "last_edited_by_table": "notion_user",
          "last_edited_time": 1549524673369,
          "parent_id": "9312ed29-a2d7-420f-9b98-ca1ea23a62c1",
          "parent_table": "block",
          "properties": {
            "title": [
              [
                "In the following example, the original type being extended is the class "
              ],
              ["string", [["c"]]],
              [". "],
              ["String", [["c"]]],
              [" has been extended by a method "],
              ["Shorten()", [["c"]]],
              [
                ", which provides the additional functionality of shortening. The static class "
              ],
              ["StringExtensions", [["c"]]],
              [
                " has been created to hold the extension method. The extension method "
              ],
              ["Shorten()", [["c"]]],
              [" shows that it is an extension of "],
              ["string", [["c"]]],
              [" via the specially marked first parameter. To show that the "],
              ["Shorten()", [["c"]]],
              [" method extends "],
              ["string", [["c"]]],
              [", the first parameter is marked with "],
              ["this", [["c"]]],
              [". Therefore, the full signature of the first parameter is "],
              ["this string text", [["c"]]],
              [", where "],
              ["string", [["c"]]],
              [" is the original type being extended and "],
              ["text", [["c"]]],
              [" is the chosen parameter name."]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "text",
          "version": 1
        }
      },

          "properties": {
            "title": [
              [
                "Note that extension methods are only usable if they are in the same namespace as their definition, if the namespace is imported explicitly by the code using the extension method, or if the extension class is namespace-less.",
                [["i"]]
              ],
              [
                " The .NET framework guidelines recommend putting extension classes in their own namespace. However, this may lead to discovery issues."
              ]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "text",
          "version": 1

          "properties": {
            "title": [
              ["An extension method is created by adding a "],
              ["static method", [["b"]]],
              [" to a "],
              ["static class", [["b"]]],
              [
                " which is distinct from the original type being extended. The static class holding the extension method is often created for the sole purpose of holding extension methods."
              ]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "text",
          "version": 5

          "parent_table": "block",
          "properties": {
            "title": [
              ["Since C# 6.0, it is also possible to put a "],
              ["using static", [["c"]]],
              [" directive to the "],
              ["class", [["i"]]],
              [" containing the extension methods. For example, "],
              ["using static System.Linq.Enumerable;", [["c"]]],
              [
                ". This makes extension methods from that particular class available without bringing other types from the same namespace into scope."
              ]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "text",
          "version": 1
        }
      },

          "last_edited_time": 1549874640000,
          "parent_id": "9312ed29-a2d7-420f-9b98-ca1ea23a62c1",
          "parent_table": "block",
          "properties": {
            "language": [["C#"]],
            "title": [
              [
                "using System.Linq; // Allows use of extension methods from the System.Linq namespace\n\nclass Program\n{\n    static void Main()\n    {\n        var ints = new int[] {1, 2, 3, 4};\n\n        // Call Where() extension method from the System.Linq namespace\n        var even = ints.Where(x => x % 2 == 0); \n    }\n}\n"
              ]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "code",
          "version": 12
        }
      }
    },
    "space": {}
  }
}
